Comment: Snippets:  >“You’re looking at substantial losses this year, about a $10bn loss this year in international travel spending relative to last year,” Sacks said.  >“It comes down to the basic principle that we’ve seen over decades, which is that travelers can go wherever they want, whenever they want. So antipathy towards a destination will have noticeable effects. It’s highly elastic to those sorts of external factors, and then you add to that the high-profile detainments which got a lot of press, particularly in Europe.”  >“The way we are perceived globally is we are blowing up not just our economy but everyone else’s economy,” Jackie Filla, president of the Hotel Association of Los Angeles, told [the LA Times](https://www.latimes.com/business/story/2025-04-12/will-trumps-tariffs-affect-californias-tourism-industry).

Author: Eat_the_Rich1789

Comment: We have international offices that would consolidate here in the US 3-4 times a year for enormous conferences. Each one of those events was outright cancelled by the end of January. None, and I mean none of my international colleagues, whether it was European or Asian or African or even Canadian felt safe or comfortable coming into the US. Sure it saved my companies tens if not hundreds of thousands in T & E budget (not like it matters to me, not like my company will give us anymore of a bonus out of the savings). But that's also that much revenue not going to our customer resorts and entertainment in Las Vegas, Miami, Denver, Seattle, New York or MSP. It has Maine downstream effects that industries are going to start really feeling once they see their Q1 earnings a fraction of what they were.
Author: J-the-Kidder
